details.title: Analysis of a simple step-stress life test with a random stress-change time

authors.affiliation: Div. of Biostat., Washington Univ. in St. Louis, MO, USA

p: Chengjie Xiong received his BS (1983) in Mathematics from Xiangtan University. He taught Mathematics at Zhangjiako Telecommunication College (1983–1986). He received his MS (1989) in Mathematics from Peking University, and his PhD (1997) in Statistics from Kansas State University. He has been with Washington University in St. Louis since 2001. He is a member of the ASA, and the International Biometrics Society. His research interests are in survival analysis, linear & nonlinear mixed models, and order restricted statistical inferences. He has published many papers on both Statistics, Biostatistics, and Mathematics.

authors.name: Chengjie Xiong

p: Kejun Zhu received his BS (1982) in Mathematics from Central China Normal University, and his MS (1987) in Mathematics from Central China University of Science and Technology. He is currently a faculty of China University of Geosciences. He has been working on system engineering for 15 years. His research interests focus on Neuro-Fuzzy & Soft Computing. He has published many papers on system engineering.

Ming Ji received his BS in Mathematics, and MS in Control Theory from East China Normal University in 1985, and 1988, respectively. He received a MS in Mathematics from Kansas State University in 1995, and then a PhD in Statistics from University of California, Davis in 1999. From 1999 to 2001, he worked as an Assistant Adjunct Professor in the Department of Family and Preventive Medicine, University of California, San Diego. He joined SDSU in August, 2001. He is member of the ASA, and the International Biometrics Society. His research interest includes: longitudinal data analysis, missing data, causal inference, medical screening tests, and microarray data analysis. He has worked on projects related to tobacco control, Alzheimer's Disease, HIV/AIDS community prevention programs, prostate cancer, and trauma center research.

details.abstract: This paper studies a variation of a simple step-stress life testing in which the stress change time is random, and the test is subject to type II censoring. We assume that only two order statistics from the test are observed. The first observed order statistic is the stress change time from a low level stress to a high level stress during the testing, and the second observed order statistic is the final failure time when the test is censored. We first present the joint probability distribution of the two order statistics observed from the simple step-stress accelerated life test. Maximum likelihood estimates, and the method of moment estimates for model parameters based on the joint distribution are considered. We also present the exact confidence interval estimates for the model parameters based on various pivotal quantities, and demonstrate the estimation procedure by a simulated example.

references.title: Optimal simple step-stress plan for Khamis-Higgins model

context.text: Alhadeed & Yang [1] discussed the optimal simple step-stress plan for a specific step-stress life testing model.

links.abstract: Optimal times of changing stress-level for the simple step-stress plans under the Khamis-Higgins model (an alternative to the Weibull step-stress model) are determined for a wide range of values of the model parameters. The applicability of the "optimal time of changing stress" formula obtained by Khamis-Higgins for a known shape parameter to the case of unknown shape parameter is examined. Their formula provides a reasonable approximation to the actual optimal times of changing stress levels wi...

references.text: A. A. Alhadeed, S. S. Yang, "Optimal simple step-stress plan for Khamis-Higgins model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 51, pp. 212-215, Jun. 2002.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring

context.text: Bai, Kim & Lee [2] further studied the similar optimum simple SSALT plan for the case where a pre-specified censoring time was involved.

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

references.text: D. S. Bai, M. S. Kim, S. H. Lee, "Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, pp. 528-532, Dec. 1989.

references.title: Optimal accelerated life designs for estimation

context.text: Chernoff [3] considered optimal life tests for estimation of model parameters based on data from ALT.

references.text: H. Chernoff, "Optimal accelerated life designs for estimation", Technometrics, vol. 4, pp. 381-408, 1962.

references.title: A Bayes approach to step-stress accelerated life testing

context.text: Dorp, Mazzuchi, Fornell & Pollock [4] developed a Bayes model, and studied the inferences of data from SSALT.

links.abstract: This paper develops a Bayes model for step-stress accelerated life testing. The failure times at each stress level are exponentially distributed, but strict adherence to a time-transformation function is not required. Rather, prior information is used to define indirectly a multivariate prior distribution for the failure rates at the various stress levels. Our prior distribution preserves the natural ordering of the failure rates in both the prior and posterior estimates. Methods are developed f...

references.text: J. R. Dorp, T. A. Mazzuchi, G. E. Fornell, L. R. Pollock, "A Bayes approach to step-stress accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 491-498, Sep. 1996.

references.title: Some experimental design problems in attribute life testing

context.text: In some other cases, intermittent inspection is the only feasible way of checking the status of test units as pointed out by Ehrenfeld [5].

references.text: S. Ehrenfeld, "Some experimental design problems in attribute life testing", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 57, pp. 668-679, 1962.

references.title: Statistical Models and Methods for Lifetime Data

context.text: Mann, Schafer & Singpurwalla [8], and Lawless [7] provided the general theory & applications of lifetime data analysis.

Thus, the conditional probability density function for \$T_{2}\$, given \$T_{1}=t_{1}\$, is (see Appendix D of Lawless [7])where \$R(t)=1-F(t)\$.

Thus, by letting \$w=F(t_{1}/\theta_{1})\$,The MME of \$\alpha\$ & \$\beta\$ can be found by solving the system of equationsWhen the lifetime is exponential under constant stress, i.e., \$f(t)=\exp(-t),t>0\$, \$ET_{1}=\theta_{1}\sum_{i=0}^{n_{1}-1}(n-i)^{-1}\$ (Lawless [7]).

references.text: J. F. Lawless, Statistical Models and Methods for Lifetime Data, 1982.

references.title: Methods for Statistical Analysis of Reliability and Life Data

context.text: Mann, Schafer & Singpurwalla [8], and Lawless [7] provided the general theory & applications of lifetime data analysis.
This seemingly restrictive SRR actually covers some of the most important models used in industry such as the Power Law model, the Eyring model, and the Arrhenius model (Mann & Schafer [8]).

references.title: Optimum accelerated life tests for Weibull and extreme value distributions and censored data

context.text: Meeker & Nelson [10] obtained optimum ALT plans for Weibull & extreme value distributions with censored data.

links.abstract: This paper presents charts for optimum accelerated life-test plans for estimating a simple linear relationship between an accelerating stress and product life, which has a Weibull or smallest extreme value distribution, when the data are to be analyzed before all tests units fail. The plans show that one need not run all test units to failure and that more units ought to be tested at low test stresses than at high ones. The plans are illustrated with a voltage-accelerated life test of an electri...

references.text: W. Q. Meeker, W. B. Nelson, "Optimum accelerated life tests for Weibull and extreme value distributions and censored data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-24, pp. 321-332, Dec. 1975.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing

context.text: Miller & Nelson [11] studied optimum test plans which minimized the asymptotic variance of the MLE of the mean life at a design stress for simple SSALT where all units were run to failure.
The cumulative exposure model has been used by many authors to model data from SSALT (Nelson [12]–[14], Miller & Nelson [11], Yin & Sheng [23]).
More specifically, let \$\xi=(x_{1}-x_{0})/(x_{2}-x_{1})\$ be the amount of stress extrapolation (Miller & Nelson [11]).

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum plans for simple (two stresses) step-stress tests where all units are run to failure. Such plans minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the mean life at a design stress. The life-test model consists of: 1) an exponential life distribution with 2) a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and 3) a cumulative exposure model for the effect of changing stress. Two types of simple step-stress tests are considered: 1) a time-step...

references.text: R. W. Miller, W. B. Nelson, "Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-32, pp. 59-65, Apr. 1983.

references.title: Accelerated life testing&#821step-stress models and data analysis

context.text: Nelson [12] considered data from SSALT, and obtained MLE for the parameters of a Weibull distribution under the inverse power law using the breakdown time data of an electrical insulation.
The cumulative exposure model has been used by many authors to model data from SSALT (Nelson [12]–[14], Miller & Nelson [11], Yin & Sheng [23]).

links.abstract: This paper presents statistical models and methods for analyzing accelerated life-test data from step-stress tests. Maximum likelihood methods provide estimates of the parameters of such models, the life distribution under constant stress, and other information. While the methods are applied to the Weibull distribution and inverse power law, they apply to many other accelerated life test models. These methods are illustrated with step-stress data on time to breakdown of an electrical insulation.

references.text: W. B. Nelson, "Accelerated life testing̵step-stress models and data analysis", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-29, pp. 103-108, Jun. 1980.

references.title: Accelerated Life Testing, Statistical Models, Test Plans, and Data Analysis

context.text: Nelson [13], [14] provided an extensive & comprehensive source for theory, and examples for ALT & SSALT.
The cumulative exposure model has been used by many authors to model data from SSALT (Nelson [12]–[13][14], Miller & Nelson [11], Yin & Sheng [23]).
Chapter 10 of Nelson [13] extensively studied cumulative exposure models when the stress is changed at pre-specified times.

According to assumption 3, the conditional Cdf \$G_{T\vert T_{1}}\$ of \$T\$, given the stress change time \$T_{1}=t_{1}\$, is given by the classic cumulative exposure model (Nelson [13]):where \$s=t_{1}\theta_{2}/\theta_{1}\$.

links.abstract: Presents nearly coincident observations of backscattering from the ERS-1 SAR and of near-surface temperature from drifting buoys in the Beaufort Sea during 1991 and 1992, showing that the onset of melt and fall freeze-up can be detected precisely in the SAR data. Melt onset is marked by a clean steep decrease in backscattering from multiyear ice at 5.3 GHz. The authors show that this decrease is due solely to the appearance of liquid water in snow covering the multiyear ice. Freeze-up is marked ...

context.text: Seo & Yum [16] also proposed several approximate ML estimators, and compared them with the MLE by a Monte-Carlo simulation when the lifetime distribution is assumed exponential.

links.abstract: For grouped and censored data from an exponential distribution, the method of maximum likelihood (ML) does not in general yield a closed-form estimate of the mean, and therefore, an iterative procedure must be used. Considered are three approximate estimators of the mean: two approximate ML estimators and the midpoint estimator. Their performances are compared by Monte Carlo simulation to those of the ML estimator, in terms of the mean square error and bias. The two approximate ML estimators are...

references.text: S. K. Seo, B. J. Yum, IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 42, pp. 87-96, Mar. 1993.

references.title: A least-square approach to analyzing life-stress relationship in step-stress accelerated life tests

context.text: Teng & Yeo [18] used the method of least-square to estimate the life-stress relationship in step-stress accelerated life tests.

links.abstract: A new approach is proposed for the data analysis of failure-censored step-stress accelerated life tests with exponential failures, following an assumed log-linear life-stress relationship. This approach, transformed least squares: (1) provides closed-form parameter estimates; (2) motivates a simple statistic for life-stress relationship verification; and (3) appreciably simplifies the derivation of optimal test plans. The proposed D-statistic has good power and compares reasonably well with like...

references.text: S. L. Teng, K. P. Yeo, "A least-square approach to analyzing life-stress relationship in step-stress accelerated life tests", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 51, pp. 177-182, Jun. 2002.

references.title: Nonparametric model for step-stress accelerated life testing

context.text: Tyoskin & Krivolapov [19] presented a nonparametric approach for making inferences for SSALT data.

links.abstract: A nonparametric model of the interval estimation is proposed. The estimation is based on results of step-stress accelerated life testing. The approach includes: application of a linear model of damage accumulation, which is proved to be equivalent to the assumptions accepted in numerous papers; estimation of the time transformation function, using the test results for all the load levels; and application of a nonparametric approach for interval estimation of reliability measures, based on the as...

references.text: O. I. Tyoskin, S. Y. Krivolapov, "Nonparametric model for step-stress accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 346-350, Jun. 1996.

references.title: Inferences on a simple step-stress model with type II censored exponential data

context.text: Xiong [20] obtained inferences based on pivotal quantities for type II censored exponential data from a simple SSALT.

links.abstract: This paper presents the inferences of parameters on the simple step-stress model in accelerated life testing with type-II censoring. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. Maximum likelihood methods are used to estimate the parameters of these models. Hypothesis tests about model parameters are discussed. Confidence intervals for parameter-estimates are constructed using a pivotal quantity. The advantage ...

references.text: C. Xiong, "Inferences on a simple step-stress model with type II censored exponential data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 47, pp. 142-146, Jun. 1998.

references.title: Step-stress life-testing with random stress-change times for exponential data

context.text: Xiong [21] studied the statistical inferences for a SSALT with random stress change times when individual failure times are actually observed.

The conditional pdf \$g(t\vert t_{1})\$ of \$T\$, given \$T_{1}=t_{1}\$, is thenThe marginal pdf of step-stress lifetime \$T\$ is given by \$g(t\vert t_{1})l(t_{1})\$, which is also discussed in details by Xiong [21].
The process of similar data simulation was also discussed in Xiong [20], [21].

links.abstract: This paper studies statistical models in step-stress accelerated life-testing when the stress-change times are random. The marginal lifetime distribution of a test unit under a step-stress test plan when the stress change times are random variables is presented. Maximum likelihood estimates for model parameters based on both the marginal and conditional life distributions are considered. An optimum test plan is explored for simple step-stress test when the stress change time is an order statisti...

references.text: C. Xiong, "Step-stress life-testing with random stress-change times for exponential data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 48, pp. 141-148, Jun. 1999.

context.text: The cumulative exposure model has been used by many authors to model data from SSALT (Nelson [12]–[14], Miller & Nelson [11], Yin & Sheng [23]).

links.abstract: This paper uses some basic assumptions to derive the life distribution of product under accelerated life testing by progressive stress, when the life distribution under design constant stress follows an exponential or a Weibull distribution. It discusses the special case when the acceleration equation satisfies the inverse power law and progressive stress is directly proportional to time. Maximum likelihood (ML) methods estimators are derived and their properties are discussed, eg, invariance, u...
